Question 1: The peripheral smear of a patient with chronic fatigue is shown below. This marked finding is 
seen in all of the conditions except
questions.explanation:
The given peripheral smear shows Howell–Jolly bodies. They are not seen in paroxysmal 
nocturnal hemoglobinuria. They are small nuclear remnants seen as inclusions in red cells and are characteristic of 
asplenia. They are seen in the following conditions: • Sickle cell anaemia - due to auto splenectomy • Hereditary spherocytosis • Thalassemia post-splenectomy The images given below show Howell–Jolly bodies in peripheral blood smear. 384 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: 373 
Sold by @itachibot Which chromosome is affected in alpha-thalassemia?
questions.explanation:
385 
Sold by @itachibot Chromosome 16 contains an identical pair of -globin genes which is affected in 
alpha-thalassemia. This condition is due to decreased synthesis of alpha chains. The two  chains are encoded by a single  -globin gene on chromosome 11.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements is false regarding -thalassemia?

options.a: Free  and  chains are more soluble than free  chains
options.c:  chains are coded by a pair of genes
options.d: Hb Barts is the most severe form

questions.explanation:
 chains are coded by 4 genes i.e. two pairs of genes located on chromosome 16. Free  and  chains are more soluble than free  chains. They also form more stable 
homotetramers. Hence, hemolysis and dyserythropoiesis in  thalassemia are less severe when 
compared to  thalassemia. In HbH disease, excess  -globin chains form  4 tetramers. They are seen in older children 
with -thalassemia. Hydrops fetalis is the most severe form of -thalassemia. It is caused by the deletion of all four 
-globin genes. This leads to excess -globin chains forming -globin tetramers (hemoglobin 
Barts).

questions.question:
Question 5: A woman with an obstetric score of G3P2A0L0, in a consanguinous marriage, delivered a 
hydropic stillborn at 32 weeks of gestation. Further evaluation revealed the presence of Hb 
Barts in the fetal blood. Which of the following globin chains tetramer is found in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
Hb Barts is a tetramer of -globin chains (4). This type of hemoglobin is seen in newborns with 
the most severe form of -thalassemia and results in hemoglobin Barts hydrops fetalis. There is 
no production of  chains. Hb Barts has a higher affinity for oxygen. This leads to intrauterine hypoxia, eventually leading to 
stillbirth. The image given below shows (a) immature red cell precursors in peripheral smear and (b) 
stillborn hydropic infant in Hb Barts hydrops syndrome. 386 
Sold by @itachibot In HbH disease, excess  -globin chains form  4 tetramers. They are seen in older children 
with -thalassemia.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 26-year-old Chinese translator presents with fever, jaundice and splenomegaly. His Hb is 6 
g% and peripheral smear with brilliant cresyl blue is given below. Which of the following 
globin chains would you expect to see in this patient? 374 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of extravascular hemolysis (jaundice and splenomegaly) and peripheral 
smear showing golf ball cells is suggestive of HBH disease. It is a type of  thalassemia where the 
HbH is composed of tetramers of  chains ( 4). Hb-H disease is one type of alpha-thalassaemia with inactivation of 3 of the 4 alleles. It is more 
common in the Asian population. It usually manifests in the 1st year of life. It causes acute 
episodes of hemolysis when triggered by infections or oxidant drugs. The decreased  chain production leads to a relative excess of  chains. This leads to the 
formation of HbH which has a high affinity for oxygen. Such RBCs are more prone to oxidation 
which causes precipitation of HbH to form golf ball inclusion bodies. This leads to increased 
sequestration and phagocytosis in the spleen.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient has a HbA2 of 3% and HbF of 97%. A peripheral blood smear is taken. Which of the 
following blood pictures will be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The presence of HbA2 3% and HbF 97% indicates that it is a case of thalassemia major. In 
thalassemia major, hematological findings in image 1 showing poikilocytes and image 3 showing 
target cells are seen. Image 2 showing Howell Jolly bodies are seen in post-splenectomy 
thalassemia patients and not in this case. Hematological findings in thalassemia major include the following: • Anisopoikilocytosis • Target cells (codocytes) • Nucleated RBC’s • Dacrocytes • Basophilic stippling • Polychromatophilic cells 387 
Sold by @itachibot Howell Jolly body Target 
Cells 3. 388 
Sold by @itachibot

Question 9: The following test was performed with blood sample from a patient with anaemia. What is 
this test used for?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility test. It 
is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings. The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is 
performed as follows: • Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution. • Shake the tube and leave it at room temperature for 30 minutes. • Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text or

questions.question:
Question 10: A couple with a family history of thalassemia comes for genetic counselling. Their HPLC 
reports are given below. What is the risk of their offspring having thalassemia major?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the risk of their offspring having thalassemia major is 0%. From the given HPLC reports, the husband is normal (normal value of HbA2 is 2.5%±0.3%) and 
the wife has  thalassemia minor (HbA2 level 4.9%). This disease is transmitted with an 
autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the chance of their offspring having full blown 
thalassemia is zero. In  thalassemia minor, the Hb A2 levels are increased to 4–8%. This is due to an elevated ratio of 
 chain to  chain synthesis. Hb F levels are generally normal or slightly increased. Note: Increased HbF (diagnostic) and normal HbA2 levels are features of thalassemia major.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 25-year old man presents with chronic anemia and gall stones. His family history is 
significant for a similar illness. His peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the mode 
of the inheritance of the given clinical condition?
questions.explanation:
The given peripheral smear showing spherocytes, along with the history, is suggestive 
of hereditary spherocytosis. Inheritance of this condition is mainly autosomal dominant. Hereditary spherocytosis is a structural RBC disorder making the RBCs more spheroid. The RBCs 
are less deformable and more vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction. This decreases 
the lifespan of RBCs.

questions.question:
Question 12: What is the most common protein deficiency associated with hereditary spherocytosis? 377 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
390 
Sold by @itachibot Ankyrin is the most common protein deficiency associated with hereditary spherocytosis (HS). The chief protein component of the RBC membrane skeleton is spectrin. It consists of two 
polypeptide chains, alpha and beta. These dimers associate with actin oligomers. The spectrin–
actin skeleton is then connected to the cell membrane by two distinct interactions. • Ankyrin and band 4.2 binds spectrin to the transmembrane ion transporter, band 3 • Protein 4.1 binds the tail of spectrin to the transmembrane protein glycophorin A Defect in any of the components of the red cell membrane skeleton results in hereditary 
spherocytosis. The image given below shows the pathogenesis of this condition. Note: Few one-liners on membrane skeleton - • Most abundant integral proteins - glycophorin, band 3 • Responsible for biconcave shape of RBC - spectrin • Most severe deficiency - spectrin • Hereditary elliptocytosis is due to deficiency of alpha spectrin • Mushroom cells appearance due to deficiency of band 3 • Never involved in HS - glycophorin

questions.question:
Question 13: The peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia, jaundice and splenomegaly shows pincer 
cells. Which protein deficiency is responsible for this finding?
questions.explanation:
Pincer cell or mushroom cell is seen in hereditary spherocytosis associated with deficiency 
of cytoskeletal protein band 3. 391 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following features would you least expect to see in a patient with hereditary 
spherocytosis?
questions.explanation:
Hemoglobinuria is not seen in hereditary spherocytosis where extravascular hemolysis occurs. It 
is a feature of intravascular hemolysis. Pigment gallstones, pallor and splenomegaly can be seen in 
this condition. Cinical features of extravascular hemolysis include: • Anaemia • Jaundice • Splenomegaly Causes of extravascular hemolysis: • Hereditary spherocytosis • Thalassemia • Sickle cell anaemia Note: G6PD deficiency and autoimmune hemolytic anaemia can cause both intravascular and 
extravascular hemolysis.

questions.question: Question 15: What is the life span of affected red cells in patients with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.explanation:
The life span of affected red cells in hereditary spherocytosis is 10 to 20 days. The normal life 
span of RBC is 120 days.

questions.question:
Question 16: 378 
Sold by @itachibot In a patient with hereditary spherocytosis, MCHC of 38 g/dL was noted. What could be the 
probable reason for this finding?
questions.explanation:
392 
Sold by @itachibot Increased MCHC in hereditary spherocytosis is due to dehydration caused by the loss of K+ and 
H2O. MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) is given by the formula hemoglobin / PCV 
(g/dL). It indicates the amount of hemoglobin per unit volume. Note: • MCV (mean corpuscular volume) is given by the formula PCV / RBC (fL). It denotes the size of 
the RBCs. • MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) is given by the formula hemoglobin / RBC (pg). It 
quantifies the hemoglobin in the RBCs.

questions.question:
Question 17: In the following osmotic fragility curve, A occurs in  
.
questions.explanation:
Osmotic fragility curve shifts to the right in hereditary spherocytosis. In hereditary spherocytosis, the cells are spherocytic in normal plasma (0.9% NaCl) 
and hemolyse readily at higher concentrations than normal discoid red cells do, hence shifting the 
curve to the right. Osmotic fragility is the susceptibility of the RBC to rupture under osmotic stress. 
In hypotonic solutions, RBCs swell to become spherical and eventually hemolyse. In the graph, 
the x-axis represents the saline concentration while the y-axis represents the percentage of red 
cells that have undergone hemolysis. When osmotic fragility is normal, red cells begin to 
hemolyse at 0.5% saline, with 50% of hemolysis occuring at 0.40-0.42% saline and complete 
hemolysis occuring at 0.35% saline as represented in the curve. In thalassemia and sickle cell anemia on the other hand, the cells are resistant to hemolysis and 
don’t hemolyse unless the concentration of saline is very low, shifting the graph to the left. 393 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A 7-year-old girl presents with fever and jaundice for 5 days. On examination, splenomegaly 
is noted. Her lab reports are given below. What is the likely trigger to have caused this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given hemogram showing pancytopenia and spherocytes in peripheral smear is suggestive of 
aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis. It is usually triggered by parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infects and kills the red cell precursors. This creates a transient arrest of erythropoiesis 
i.e. aplastic crisis as the life span of RBCs are shortened. The immune response clears the virus in 
1-2 weeks. Blood transfusions may be necessary during acute phases of the infection. This crisis can also 
occur in other hemolytic anaemias.

questions.question: Question 19: Which amino acid lies at the sixth position of the beta chain of hemoglobin?
questions.explanation:
Glutamate lies at the 6th position of the beta chain of hemoglobin. Sickle-cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of  -globin. This leads to the 
replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.

questions.question:
Question 20: A blood sample is taken from a suspected case of sickle cell anaemia. Which of the following 
properties can be used to differentiate HbS from HbA?
questions.explanation:
Solubility can be used to differentiate as HbS is less soluble than HbA. The function, stability and 
affinity of HbS are similar to that of HbA. In HbS, glutamic acid, which is a polar amino acid, is replaced by a non-polar amino acid valine at 
the 6th position. HbS molecules have the tendency to stack into polymers when 
deoxygenated. This process converts the red cell cytosol from a free-flowing liquid into a viscous 
gel. This causes a change in the solubility of the hemoglobin. The major pathologic manifestations of decreased solubility and polymerisation of HbS are 
chronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 35-year-old man was diagnosed to have heterozygous sickle cell trait. What will be the 
approximate percentage of HbS in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In heterozygotes with sickle-cell trait, about 40% of the hemoglobin is HbS. The rest of 
hemoglobin (60%) is HbA. Sickle cell trait is a largely asymptomatic condition characterised by heterozygosity seen for HbS 
(sickle hemoglobin). As only a fraction of the Hb are HbS, polymerization leading to sickling only 
occurs in severe and prolonged hypoxia. Offsprings of 2 heterozygotes have a 1 in 4 chance of 
having sickle cell disease. In HbSC heterozygotes, HbS is 50% and HbC is 50%.

questions.question:
Question 22: Patients with which of the following combinations of beta-globin chains tend to have a more 
severe sickle cell disease?
questions.explanation:
394 
Sold by @itachibot Among the given options, the heterozygous combination of HbS and HbC causes a more severe 
form of the disease. Overall severity is more in homozygous HbS. Severity sequence is HbSS > HbSC > HbSA > HbSF. In HbC, lysine is substituted for glutamate in the sixth amino acid residue of  -globin. The 
percentage of HbS is 50% in HbSC red cells and 40% in HbAS cells. Moreover, HbSC cells tend to 
lose salt and water and become dehydrated, which increases the intracellular concentration of 
HbS. Both of these factors increase the tendency for HbS to polymerize. As a result, individuals 
who are compound heterozygotes for HbS and HbC, have symptomatic sickling disorder (termed 
HbSC disease). However, it is milder than sickle cell disease (HbSS). HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS even more than HbA. Hence, infants do not become 
symptomatic until they reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.

questions.question: Question 23: In patients with sickle cell anaemia, which of the following factors promote sickling of RBC?
questions.explanation:
HbC promotes the sickling of RBC, whereas HbF opposes it. Factors that promote sickling are: • Increased MCHC • Hb C • Acidic pH • Hypoxia HbF has a high affinity for oxygen than other hemoglobins. Hence, high oxygen content prevents 
sickling. HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS. So the infants do not become symptomatic until 
they reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following reagents is used for sickling test?
questions.explanation:
The reagent used for the sickling test is sodium metabisulfite. It is an oxygen-consuming 
reagent, which induces the sickling of red cells in the presence of HbS. Sickling test with sodium metabisulfite is used as a screening test for sickle cell anaemia.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 12-year-old girl presents with fever and severe pain in her hands and feet. There is no 
history of trauma. Her lab reports reveal Hb to be 8.2 g/dL and peripheral smear as shown 
below. Which of the following parasitic infections is this condition protective against? 381 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sickle cell anaemia. HbS gives protection against 
Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of bones of hands and feet is a severe acute inflammatory 
response seen in sickle cell anaemia. It is caused by vaso-occlusive episodes leading to ischemia 
and finally infarction of the distal portions of the extremities. 395 
Sold by @itachibot Sickle cells impair the formation of membrane knobs containing a protein made by P. falciparum 
called PfEMP-1. This decreases the adherence of infected red cells to the endothelium. Individuals with sickle cell trait are significantly less likely to have severe disease or to die from 
malaria. It is because of the increased phagocytosis of sickled cells in the spleen, which keeps the 
parasite load down. The image given below shows sickle cells seen on peripheral smear in sickle cell anemia.

questions.question:
Question 26: What happens to the severity of hemolytic anaemia in concurrent sickle cell anaemia and 
-thalassemia?
questions.explanation:
The concurrence of sickle cell anaemia and -thalassemia results in less severe hemolytic 
anaemia. Sickle cell anaemia is caused by point mutations in  globin synthesis leading to defective HbS 
synthesis. When these RBCs release oxygen, the HbS polymerises leading to membrane distortion Thalassemia is due to germline mutations causing decreased globin chain synthesis ( or  ). Since 
these diseases have a different pathogenesis, they can occur concurrently. In alpha-thalassemia, the concentration of hemoglobin is decreased. Therefore the concentration 
of HbS in sickle cell anaemia is also decreased. Since HbS molecules should be close to each other 
for polymerization to occur. Since there is a decreased concentration of HbS in alpha-thalassemia, 
the HbS molecules are far apart. So there is a decreased polymerization of HbS and therefore less 
severity of the disease.

questions.question:
Question 27: A 23-year-old patient with sickle cell anaemia presents with fever and malaise. IgM ELISA 
confirms a parvovirus B19 infection. Which of the following crises will you expect to see in 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aplastic crisis in sickle cell anaemia is caused by parvovirus B19. It is a transient arrest of 
erythropoiesis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infects and kills red 
cell precursors. It occurs in sickle cell disease and other hemolytic anaemias. 396 
Sold by @itachibot Vaso-occlusive crises (pain crises) are episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe 
pain in the affected region. The most commonly involved sites are the bones, lungs, liver, brain, 
spleen, and penis. Acute chest syndrome is a type of vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs. It 
typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Pulmonary 
inflammation may cause blood flow to become sluggish and “spleenlike,” leading to sickling and 
vaso-occlusion. Sequestration crises occur in children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells 
leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock. Both sequestration crises 
and acute chest syndrome may be fatal and sometimes require prompt treatment with exchange 
transfusions.

questions.question:
Question 28: During USG examination in a patient with hemolytic anemia, the spleen was not visualized. 
There is no past history of trauma or surgery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Non-visualisation of the spleen on routine USG is suggestive of autosplenectomy, which is seen in 
sickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis. In children with sickle cell anaemia, there is moderate splenomegaly. This is due to red pulp 
congestion caused by the entrapment of sickled red cells. As age advances, chronic erythrostasis 
produces hypoxic damage and infarcts. By adulthood, the spleen is reduced to a band of fibrous 
tissue. This process is called autosplenectomy. 397 
Sold by @itachibot G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias
